Award.AwardTitle: Standard Research Grant: Representational Materialities of Internet Protocols

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on representational materialities of the digital environment. It will study the material properties and consequences of the way that bits are arranged in wires, data structures are organized on disks, databases are arranged to support specific kinds of operations, and textual and graphical representations are designed for human visual and cognitive processing. This project will contribute to the developing field of software studies by studying our internet as a historically- and geographically-specific object. The project will broaden our understanding of the network beyond a designed object to an evolving object. Findings will speak to public concerns and policies over internet regulation and network neutrality.

This research project will focus on digital infrastructures, the representational considerations in the design of Internet protocols, and the digital conventions that structure network operations. The approach will combine technoscientific materialities with insights from the emerging field of Software Studies to document the significance to digital users and policy-makers, as well as, the competing interests and requirements. The project will also include interviews with people who have played leading roles in the development of these systems. The project will contribute to interdisciplinary collaboration and engagement between technologists, social scientists, policymakers, and regulators by unpacking the ways in which protocols act as sites of power, influence, and control, and the political rationalities and relationalities that they embody, provides opportunities for reflection, intervention, reconfiguration, and accountability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From search engine policy to misinformation on social media, we know that the configuration of networked technologies holds deep consequences for society. However, conversations about oversight, regulation, or policy remedies focus largely on the institutional contexts in which those networked technologies are developed or deployed, suggesting that the relevant considerations lie in how technologies are applied but not within the technologies themselves. Research into the materialities of network protocols illustrates that, to the contrary, aspects of how those technologies are themselves designed also contribute to the social realities. Design choices made in the development of network protocols ? such as what protocols represent, how those representations can be used to express desired sociotechnical arrangements, and how those expressions match the configurations of physical infrastructure, software architecture, and organizational structure ? shape our experience of the technologies and services that they support. This project set out to understand these processes of shaping.

A major emerging focus of the research has been the way that protocols are adapted and evolve over time. One example concerns IP, the Internet Protocol. The TCP/IP protocols at the heart of the internet were first developed in the 1970s and early 1980s. In the 1990s, when designers began to see some of their potential failings, a new protocol (IPv6) was developed but is still not widely used (although it is widely deployed). Rather, a series of smaller adjustments allowed the older protocols to continue to work, albeit with adjusted expectations of their functionality. Hardware platforms evolve, infrastructures evolve, and services evolve, and each of these essentially re-materializes network protocols by reconfiguring their relationship to physical objects and spaces. Security, for example, must be reimagined in the context of the increasing adoption of the Internet and especially with the growth of wireless networking; but at the same time, the increasing computational capacities of network end-points (like phones) mean that solutions like public key cryptography, initially too costly to be deployed uniformly, can now be widely distributed.

Examining closely the specific designs of core network protocols like IP and DNS allows us to see these effects in practice. The focus on evolution speaks to two concerns. The first is expandability ? what features of design shape how the capacity of a protocol to be extended and expanded beyond its initial applications and with what consequences for control and management. The second is the way that the evolution of representational systems like protocols must be matched to evolution of other elements of the sociotechnical system, including networks (and their providers), devices (and their owners), and standards bodies (and their members). There is no one way that this plays out, and we have proposed the idea of ?matched evolution? to begin to characterize the different patterns of development that shape networked futures.

Given the ever increasing role that networked technologies play in everyday life, this research is now supporting new engagements between designers, social scientists, and policy experts concerning how the next generation of network protocols (and not just services) might be designed to ensure robust support for freedoms of expression and assembly.
